trans-unit.source:
References

  • Opinion 06/2014 on the notion of legitimate interests of the data controller under Article 7 of Directive 95/46/EC
  • https://ec.europa.eu/justice/article-29/documentation/opinion-recommendation/files/2014/wp217_en.pdf
  • https://ec.europa.eu/justice/article-29/documentation/opinion-recommendation/files/2013/wp203_en.pdf
  • https://help.unhcr.org/czech/safe-online/
  • https://europa.eu/youreurope/citizens/consumers/internet-telecoms/data-protection-online-privacy/index_en.htm#inline-nav-1
  • https://eur-lex.europa.eu/eli/reg/2016/679/oj
  • https://ec.europa.eu/newsroom/article29/items/623051/en

Glossary

  • Advertising ID – A unique number on your phone or device used by apps and companies to show you targeted ads.
  • Anonymisation – A process of changing personal data so that a person can no longer be identified.
  • Anonymised data – Personal data that has been changed so that it can no longer be linked to a specific person.
  • Basic personal data – Common details like name, birthday, phone number, or home address.
  • Children’s data – Personal information that belongs to people under 18 years old.
  • Consent – Your clear agreement that allows an organisation to collect or use your personal data for a specific purpose.
  • Contractual basis – When personal data is processed because it is necessary to carry out a contract with you.
  • Cookie ID – A small piece of data stored in your browser that identifies your activity on websites.
  • Data breach – A security incident where personal data is accidentally or unlawfully accessed, shared, stolen, or lost.
  • Data controller – The person or organisation that decides why and how personal data is collected and is responsible for keeping it safe and using it legally.
  • Data processor – A person or organisation that handles personal data on behalf of the data controller, following instructions without making their own decisions.
  • Data protection principles – The basic rules under GDPR that organisations must follow when collecting and using personal data.
  • Data subject – The individual whose personal data is collected and processed.
  • Digital consent age – The minimum age at which a child can give valid consent to use online services that collect personal data (usually 16 under GDPR, but can be lowered to 13 in some EU countries).
  • Employment data – Information about your work, such as job position, salary, or work history.
  • Encryption – A method of protecting data by turning it into a coded form that can only be read with a special key.
  • Financial data – Information about your money, bank account, or payments.
  • General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) – The main EU law that sets rules on how personal data must be collected, used, and protected.
  • IP address – A unique number given to your device when it connects to the internet.
  • Legal obligation – When the law requires personal data to be collected or stored.
  • Legitimate interest – A legal basis that allows an organisation to use data if it has a clear, real purpose, and if this does not outweigh people’s rights and freedoms.
  • Marketing data – Personal information collected by companies to promote or advertise products and services.

In Alphabetical Order

  • Non-personal data – Information that cannot be linked to a specific person, such as a company registration number or the number of visitors to a website.
  • Online identifiers & behavioural data – Information about how you use the internet, like your IP address, search history, or online habits.
  • Parental consent – Verified agreement from a parent or legal guardian that allows a child’s personal data to be collected or used.
  • Patient number – A code in a hospital or medical system that refers to a specific patient instead of using their name.
  • Personal data – Any information that can identify a person directly or indirectly.
  • Public task – When public institutions process data as part of their official duties.
  • Sensitive personal data – Private information such as religion, health condition, or immigration status that requires stronger protection.
  • Vital interests – A legal basis that allows data to be used in order to protect someone’s life or health.
trans-unit.target:
